repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Rural Finance Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Rural Finance Technical Assistance
            Project in Madagascar. It aimed at promoting a durable
            savings and loan movement at the grass-roots level which
            would provide sound financial services to its members, and
            over time link up with formal institutions. It was also
            intended to address the legal and regulatory issues involved
            in the development of the savings and loan movement.
            Overall, the Bank performed satisfactorily throughout the
            project cycle. The performance of the Borrower was
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned were as follows: (a)
            significant human and material resources are required to
            build solid and healthy institutions; (b) until the savings
            culture is completely internalized, deposit mobilization
            rather than external lines of credit should be persistently
            and consistently maintained as basis for sustainable
            capability to lend; (c) to balance cost and progress toward
            self-sustainability, it is evident that the Savings and Loan
            Association (SLA) networks must also move into urban areas
            where population density is higher and savings are more
            important; (d) where the need is identified and warranted,
            financing should be provided to assist SLA networks set up
            appropriate Management Information System (MIS) and
            accounting systems; (e) funds should be earmarked for
            mandatory external operational and financial audit of the
            SLA networks once they reach a given level of assets; (f)
            setting real positive interest rates on loans provides SLAs
            with sufficient margins for cost recovery and put them on
            the path to self-sustainability; and (g) government should
            establish a mechanism to coordinate activities of competing
            rural finance schemes.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Rural Finance Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The key objective of the Rural Finance
            Technical Assistance Project is to stimulate and support the
            creation of a savings and loan movement at the grass-roots
            level which can provide financial services on a sustainable
            basis to its members, and over time develop banking and
            borrowing relationships with formal institutions. The
            project includes:  (a) establishment of Savings and Loan
            Associations (SLAs) in which all forms of savings, including
            savings in kind, will be tested; (b) support for project
            management, monitoring and evaluation, by the Mutual Savings
            and Loan Development Association, which has been established
            as a non-government association; and (c) services to develop
            off-farm activities through basic and entrepreneurship
            training in rural areas.  The project will not provide any
            monies for SLA lending.
